title: Lionel Messi and Cristiano Ronaldo are responsible for Spain’s Champions League dominance, claims Sir Alex Ferguson
text:
Sir Alex Ferguson won the Champions League twice with Manchester Untied in 1999 and 2008 (Picture: Getty) Sir Alex Ferguson believes Spain’s Champions League dominance will come to an end once Barcelona and Real Madrid are forced to contemplate replacing Cristiano Ronaldo and Lionel Messi.
Diego Simeone reveals how Manchester United can sign Antoine Griezmann this summer The Liga giants have won Europe’s biggest club prize in each of the last three seasons, while Atletico Madrid have twice been beaten finalists during that period.
Spain’s big three sides have again made the last eight of this season’s competition, while England’s only representatives are champions Leicester, who face the daunting task of getting past Diego Simeone’s men if they are to make it to the semi finals.
Lionel Messi helped Barcelona prevent Sir Alex Ferguson from winning a third Champions League win in 2009 and 2011 (Picture: Getty) Ronaldo won the Champions League with Man United in 2008 and has tasted success with Real Madrid in 2014 and 2016 (Picture: Getty) The former Manchester United manager, who twice won Europe’s biggest club prize in 1999 and 2008, accepts Spain are currently enjoying a golden period, but is confident their success will subside as Ronaldo and Messi enter the latter stages of their club careers.
‘(Now) the domain is in Spain. There’s no question about that,’ Ferguson told ESPN FC.
Champions League Winners | 2016 - 2010 2016: Real Madrid
2015: Barcelona
2014: Real Madrid
2013: Bayern Munich
2012: Chelsea
2011: Barcelona
2010: Inter

‘The same question could be asked about the German teams, why are Bayern Munich not winning the Champions League? Why are the Italians not winning it? Why are the French not winning it?
